FacilityName: Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC - Kirkland, IL Fac

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Illinois Department of Agriculture and Industry Standards (Aqua)
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Aqua Ammonia S&H (Covered Process 3): 



The Facility Operations Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMP) for the RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  Although the process is not subject to the OSHA PSM rules, the Facility has incorporated this process into its PSM/RMP combined management plan.  The PSM/RMP includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



This Facility stores and handles a 25% ammonia concentrated solution in a 30,000-gallon aboveground storage tank (AST).  The process equipment includes the AST and ancillary process piping, valves, and transfer hose.   



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the storage of aqua ammonia in the AST.  These operations are conducted in accordance with the PSM/RMP Operating Procedures.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMP Mechanical Integrity Procedures.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: Installed emergency shutoff valves and electric actuators.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Inspection post installation of the emergency shutoff valves and electric actuators.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Anhydrous Ammonia S&H (Covered Process 1): 



The Facility Operations Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMP) for the OSHA and RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  The PSM/RMP includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



This Facility stores and handles anhydrous ammonia in a single stationary pressure vessel (PV).  The process equipment includes: (1) one 18,000-gallon PV and ancillary process piping, valves, liquid pump, gauges (volume, temperature, and pressure), and safety systems (electric actuated emergency shutoff valves, backflow check valve, excess flow valves, and bulkhead).



The Facility receives anhydrous ammonia by a Contractor that transports the anhydrous ammonia with a commercial cargo tank.  The commercial cargo tank is temporarily parked on the Facility property while the anhydrous ammonia is transferred to the stationary PV.  The Contractor performs the transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the commercial cargo tank to the stationary PV.  The Facility does not own or operate the commercial cargo tank.  The Contractor is responsible for training their operators and maintaining their equipment.  At a minimum, the Contractor must (1) have in place and certify compliance with applicable and relevant DOT, OSHA, state and local regulatory requirements, (2) make available to the Facility and EPA upon request any contractor-related documentation necessary to demonstrate compliance, and (3) certify that it has in place emergency shut-down procedures for anhydrous ammonia transfer operations.  The Facility coordinates with the Contractor on Emergency Contingency procedures and will provide access to the Facility PSM/RMP upon request by the Contractor.



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes: (1) overseeing the transfer of anhydrous ammonia from a commercial tanker truck to the stationary PV; (2) monitoring of temperature, volume, and pressures during storage; (3) transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the stationary PV to Nurse Tanks; and (4) transfer of anhydrous ammonia from the stationary PV to the Aqua Blending Process (Covered Process 2).  These operations are conducted in accordance with the PSM/RMP Operating Procedures.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMP Mechanical Integrity Procedures.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Process piping, transfe hoses, valves and AST
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Aqua Ammonia Blending (Covered Process 2): 



The Facility Operations Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMP) for the RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  The PSM/RMP includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



Aqua Ammonia is produced by injecting anhydrous ammonia into a column of water contained in a 30,000-gallon aboveground storage tank (AST).  The AST is physically connected by process piping and transfer hose to the 18,000-gallon anhydrous ammonia Pressure Vessel (PV).  The process equipment includes: PV; piping, valves, and transfer hose; AST; and ancillary tools to measure product quality.  



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the: (1) transfer of water into the AST; (2) transfer of anhydrous ammonia in stages into the AST; and (3) monitoring of mass and temperatures.  These operations are conducted in accordance with the PSM/RMP Operating Procedures.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMP Mechanical Integrity Procedures.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Illinois Department of Agriculture and Industry Standards (Aqua)
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism

_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Process piping, valves. actuators, liquid pumps, mix pots
_prev_prog_2.Description:
Base Blending (Covered Process 4): 



The Facility Operations Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMP) for the RMP covered process at this Facility and is assisted by other trained employees as directed.  Although the process is not subject to the OSHA PSM rules, the Facility has incorporated this process into its PSM/RMP combined management plan.  The PSM/RMP includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



The Base fertilizer product is produced by mixing aqua ammonia with water and other ingredients.  The process equipment is physically connected by process piping to the 30,000-gallon aqua ammonia aboveground storage tank (AST).  The process equipment includes: a stationary blender and ancillary process piping, valves, scale, and temperature gauges.  The blender is open top and does not have any storage capabilities for aqua ammonia. 



Trained Process Operators operate the covered process which includes the: (1) transfer of aqua ammonia, water, and other ingredients to the blender; (2) monitoring of mass and temperatures; and (3) transfer of product to storage.  These operations are conducted in accordance with the PSM/RMP Operating Procedures.  Trained personnel perform maintenance on this covered process in accordance with the PSM/RMP Mechanical Integrity Procedures.  The fertilizer product is not subject to the RMP Rule.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC Kirkland, IL Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act ? 112(r), OSHA 29 CFR ? 1910.119, and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) at 40 CFR ?68. The OSHA PSM and EPA Subpart D RMP standards are applicable to the two covered processes operated at this Facility.  This electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident, and to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



The Facility is submitting this as a 5-year update in accordance with the rule. All accident prevention elements have been reviewed and/or updated.   



It is important to note that the maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that is stored and handled at the Facility is 139,915 lbs.  Although the maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that is stored and handled at the Facility is 139,915 lbs, the total quantity reported in this EPA RMP Report is 223,864 lbs.  The reason for this is because the single anhydrous ammonia pressure vessel (i.e. 83,949 lbs) is counted a second time to account for the Aqua Blending process that is connected to the single stationary pressure vessel.  Further, the maximum quantity of aqua ammonia that is stored and handled at the Facility is 47,953 lbs.  Although the maximum quantity of aqua ammonia that is stored and handled at the Facility is 47,953 lbs, the total quantity reported in this EPA RMP Report is 95,906 lbs.  The reason for this is because the single aqua ammonia AST (i.e 47,953 lbs) is counted a second time to account for the Base Blending process that is connected to the single stationary AST.  



FACILITY



The operations at this Facility consist of chemical storage and handling, blending, retail sale and distribution.  Two chemicals (i.e. anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia greater than 20% ammon

ia concentration) are stored and handled at quantities that exceed the regulatory threshold quantity.  Covered processes operated at this Facility include:



?    Covered Process 1: Anhydrous Ammonia S&H

?    Covered Process 2: Aqua Ammonia Blending

?    Covered Process 3: Aqua Ammonia S&H

?    Covered Process 4: Base Blending





OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case and alternative case consequence analyses were completed for all four (4) covered processes.  The worst case scenario for Covered Processes 1 and 2 assumes that all the contents in the largest single pressure vessel (i.e. 18,000 gallons) are released.  The release scenario consists of the PV being punctured on the side at the ground level and the release is modeled as a ground level horizontal jet at the maximum temperature.  For the aqua ammonia (i.e. representing Covered Processes 3 and 4), the worst case release scenario assumes that the 30,000-gallon aqua ammonia AST fails and instantaneously spills the content into secondary containment that has a total containment capacity of greater than 30,000 gallons when considering displacement of the other ASTs within the containment.  The resulting release is evaporation at the maximum temperature.



Depending on the covered process, the alternative (or more likely to occur) scenario for anhydrous ammonia assumes a release of anhydrous ammonia due to (1) rupture of a 3-inch transfer hose during a loading or unloading operation associated with Covered Process 1; (2) rupture of a 1-inch transfer hose during transfer and blending at Covered Process 2; and (3) a rupture of a transfer hose and/or pipe during transfer and blending at Covered Process 3 and 4. For Covered Process 3 and 4, the release occurs within containment that has a total containment capacity of greater than 30,000 gallons when considering displacement of the other ASTs within the containment.  The resulting release is evaporation at the maximum temperature. Mitigation by engineering and admin

istrative controls is considered in these scenarios.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Operations Manager implements the risk management planning process at this Facility. The Operations Manager is assisted by other trained personnel as directed. The Operations Manager is responsible for ensuring that its employees are properly trained in the implementation of the Program 2 and 3 Accident Prevention Program elements as related to their responsibilities.  The accident prevention program elements addressed in the PSM/RMP combined program includes: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, Compliance Audits, and Trade Secrets.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



This is a non-responding Facility. The Facility has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at this Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The PSM/RMP will be updated as the Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. 



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, and 6 of EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Facility.
